contentrichtext.text: {{one source|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict= Battle of Sablat |partof=the [[Thirty Years War]] |image= [[File:Schlacht von Zablat Hogenbersche Geschichtsblätter.JPG|300px]] |caption= |date= 10 June 1619 |place=[[Budweis|Budějovice]] (present-day [[Czech Republic]]) |result= Imperial victory |combatant1={{flagicon|Bohemia}} [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]] |combatant2={{flag|Holy Roman Empire}} |commander1=[[Ernst von Mansfeld]] |commander2=[[Charles Bonaventure de Longueval, Count of Bucquoy]] |strength1=3,200 |strength2=5,000 |casualties1=1,500 dead or wounded |casualties2=650 }} {{Campaignbox Thirty Years' War Bohemian Revolt}} The '''Battle of Sablat''' or '''Záblatí''' occurred on 10 June 1619, during the [[Bohemia]]n period of the [[Thirty Years' War]]. The battle was fought between a [[Roman Catholic]] [[Imperial Army of the Holy Roman Empire|Imperial army]] led by [[Charles Bonaventure de Longueval, Count of Bucquoy]] and the [[Protestant]] army of [[Ernst von Mansfeld]]. When Mansfeld was on his way to reinforce general Hohenloe, who was besieging Budějovice ({{lang-de|[[Budweis]]}}), Buquoy intercepted Mansfeld near the small village of Záblatí ({{lang-de|Sablat}}) and brought him to battle. Mansfeld suffered defeat, losing at least 1,500 infantry and his baggage train. As a result, the Bohemians had to lift the siege of Budějovice. ==Primary sources== * Parker, Geoffrey. ''The Thirty Years' War,'' (London/New York: Routledge, 1984.
